This isn’t at all a robot, or ground breaking… it’s simply magnetic slime that is manipulated using another magnetic field to drag it where you want. All this mumbo jumbo about self healing and it going into tiny spaces to fix electrical components is nonsense. It “self heals” the same way any liquid does. Fixing electrical stuff would require you to run a parallel guide along wherever you want the slime to go… making the slime obsolete since you can obviously reach the area you want the slime to go. The electrical conductivity is also going to be quite junk. Forget about the issues you would run into if it was highly conductive.
The possible negative side of this in medicine could be that if a tiniest of particle is accidentally  left behind in a blood vessel or elsewhere could be hugely fatal.

It looks like it's controlled by magnets outside of itself. If so, It totally would need some autonomous OR radio control to be used medically, or really in ANY closed environment. It would also need to be able to see where it is as well as have a blue schematic of where it is and how to get to where it's going etc. Or, again, see where it is with a camera and a radio control so someone can move it around.

Honestly, all these videos of little "robots" moving around on flat surfaces with magnets etc just annoy me. The magnets mostly ONLY are present to enable the "robot" to be move with other magnets. They serve no other purpose... unless sure, someone swallows a chunk of metal like a battery or whatever.

Beyond that, they are utterly useless. You can't do fine grained magnetic direction inside a closed system like the body or other closed system that has internal structure that you DO NOT want to destroy.

Ergo, if you have someone swallow that slime, then say you put a magnet on the outside of their stomach, you're likely to end up ripping a whole right through the stomach, muscles and skin as the slime takes the fastest path to get to the external magnet.

The part that’s always left out of these videos is the massive setup just off camera that includes the ancillary equipment (pneumatic pumps, power systems, electromagnets, etc.) and the actual computer controlling everything. Autonomy also requires sensing.

It’s a really neat idea, and I see a lot of potential as a component of future technologies. I look forward to reading their papers once they learn more about the material properties.

EDIT: Full citation for the authors’ paper:
Sun, Mengmeng, Chenyao Tian, Liyang Mao, Xianghe Meng, Xingjian Shen, Bo Hao, Xin Wang, Hui Xie, and Li Zhang. "Reconfigurable Magnetic Slime Robot: Deformation, Adaptability, and Multifunction." Advanced Functional Materials (2022): 2112508.
